introduction.p: The flow of charges produces an electric current just as the flow of water produces a water current. While water current is quantified by the amount of water that flows per unit time through the cross-section of flow, electric current is quantified by total charge flowing per unit time through the cross-section of flow.
SI unit of current would be \text{C/s}, which is also called ampere, which is denoted as \text{A} and \text{amp}.

In metals, current flow occurs by moving conduction electrons. In semiconductors, current flow may occur either by moving conduction electrons or holes. In electrolytic cells, current flow occurs by both positive and negative ions.

figure.caption: Examples of electric current. Electric current in a metal wire is carried by conduction electrons. Electric current in an electrolytic solution is carried by both positive and negatively charged ions.

subsection.title: Electric Current in a Metal Wire
subsection.p: Let's look at current flowing in a thin wire of cross-section area A_\perp.

sidebyside.p: Let v be the speed with which electrons are drifting in the wire. We will make an assumption that all drifting electrons have the same speed. Let n be number of conduction electrons per unit volume.

subsection.p:
Since, each electron carries a charge q=-e, the charge per unit length of wire in these conduction electrons is
\lambda_e = -nA_\perp e.
Then, we will find that -neAv amount of charge flows per unit time. This is electronic current in the wire.
I_\text{electron} = -neA_\perp v.
But, the convention of electric current is to leave the sign out. Just ignoring the sign will give us wrong direction of charge flow. So, if we ignore the sign, we will also need to flip the direction of flow. Therefore, in metal, we say that electric current is
I = neA_\perp v,
which is in the opposite direction in which electron is drifting.

subsection.title: Current Density
subsection.p:
The quantity I/A_\perp gives current per unit cross-section area. It is called current density and denoted by letter J.
J = \dfrac{I}{A_\perp} = n e v.
Current density is useful when studying situations where current density varies over the cross-section. For instance, when current is flowing in a layered material with different conductivities, J will be different for different material.

Suppose current density J is same through a cylindrical wire of radius R. What will be current in the center upto a radius R/2 and what will be current in the shell of inner radius R/2 and outer radius R? Let's call the first one as I_\text{center} and the other one as I_\text{edge}.
I_\text{center} \amp = \pi J (R/2)^2 = \frac{1}{4} \pi J R^2, I_\text{edge} \amp = \pi J ( R^2 - (R/2)^2 ) = \frac{3}{4} \pi J R^2.
Clearly, current for the same thickness is higher near the edge than near the center. You might say that in a wire, most of the current flows at the edge than at the center.

For nonsteady currents, such as alternating current, current density varies across the cross-section. At high frequencies, current density is non-zero only near the surface, upto a thickness, called the skin depth.

subsection.title: Surface Current Density
subsection.p:
Current on metals flows mostly on the surface. In this case cross-section of flow is a line, whose length will be denoted by L_\perp. Therefore, in place of current density, J, we use surface current density, denote by K.
K = \dfrac{I}{L_\perp}.
In terms of drift speed v and number of electrons per unit surface area, n^\prime, this becomes
K = n^\prime e v.

sidebyside.p:
In case of a metal wire of radius R, the cross-section length will be
L_\perp = 2\pi R.

In the case of a metal sheet of length l and width w, with current flowing along the length, the cross-sectional length will be the width,
L_\perp = w.

subsection.title: Vector Current Density
subsection.p:
In some instances it is useful to define vector current densities, \vec J and \vec K by incorporating the drift velocity vector, \vec v. The vector (volume) current density \vec J for current in a metal will be in the opposite direction of the direction in which electron drifts since the charge on electron is negative.
\vec J = -ne\vec v,
where n is number density of conduction electrons, i.e., number of conduction electrons per unit volume. Similarly, the vector surface surrent density will be
\vec K = -n^\prime e \vec v,
where n^\prime is number surface density of conduction electron, i.e., number of conduction electrons per unit surface area.

exercise.title: Drift Speed of Electrons in Copper Wire

statement.p: Find drift speed of conduction electrons in a cylindrical copper wire of diameter 4\text{ mm} that carries a 10\text{ A} current.
(a) Find number density of conduction electrons.
(b) Find the drift speed of electrons.
(c) What would be the drift speed if the wire carrying 10\text{ A} current was 0.4\text{ mm}, thick, i.e. one-tenth as thick?
Data about Cu: one electron per atom as conduction electron, density = 8,960 \text{ kg/m}^3, atomic weight = 0.063546 \text{ kg/mole}, atomic number = 29.

hint.p: (a) Find number of atoms per unit volume. (b) use formula of current.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) When we divide density by atomic weight, we will get number of moles per unit volume. Let's denote that by \mu.
\mu = \dfrac{8,960 \text{ kg/m}^3}{0.063546 \text{ kg/mole}} = 141,000\text{ mole/m}^3.
There are Avogador number of atoms in one mole. And since each atom contributes one electron to conduction, the number of these electrons per unit volume will be same as number of atoms per unit volume.
n = 141,000\text{ mole/m}^3 \times 6.022\times 10^{23}\text{ mole}^{-1} = 8.49\times 10^{28}\text{ m}^{-3}.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) The area of cross-section is
A = \pi r^2 = \pi \times0.002^2 = 1.26\times 10^{-5}\text{ m}^2.
Therefore, drift speed is
v \amp = \dfrac{I}{n A e} \amp = \dfrac{10\text{ A}}{8.49\times 10^{28}\text{ m}^{-3} \times 1.26\times 10^{-5}\text{ m}^2 \times 1.6\times 10^{-19}\text{ C} } \amp = 5.84\times 10^{-5}\text{ m/s}.

solution.title: (c)
solution.p:
(c) Since drift speed is inversely proportional to A_\perp, we will just scale the result in (b) to get v here.
v_c = v_b\times \dfrac{A_b}{A_c} = v_b \times 10^2 = 5.84\times 10^{-3}\text{ m/s}.

exercise.title: Current Density and Drift Speed in a Current Carrying Copper Wire

statement.p: A steady current of 2\text{ A} flows through a gauge number 12 wire (0.0808\text{-in} diameter) made of copper. (a) Find the current density. (b) How many conducting electrons are there in one inch of the wire? (c) How many total electrons are there in a one-inch of the wire? (d) Find the drift speed of electrons.

hint.p: Start out by converting into SI units.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) Let us convert the diameter from inch into meter first.
D = 0.0808\:\text{in}\times \dfrac{0.0254\:\text{m}}{1\:\text{in}} = 2.05\times 10^{-3}\:\text{m}.
The area of cross-section,
A = \dfrac{\pi}{4}\:D^2 = 3.31\times 10^{-6}\:\text{m}^2.
Hence, the current density is
J = \dfrac{I}{A} = \dfrac{2\:\text{A}}{3.31\times 10^{-6}\:\text{m}^2} = 6.05\times 10^{5}\:\text{A}/\text{m}^2.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) The number of mobile electrons in one inch of the wire can be obtained from the number of atoms of copper since each atom contributes one electron to the conduction.
\text{No. of cond. electrons} \amp = \text{No. of atoms}\times \text{No. of cond. electrons/atom} \amp = \text{No. of atoms}\times 1 = \text{No. of atoms}.
Now, the number of atoms in one inch of copper wire will be
N_{\text{atoms}} \amp = \text{Volume} \times \text{Density} \times \dfrac{1}{\text{At. Wt.}}\times \text{Avo. No}. \amp = (2.54\:\text{cm}\times 0.0331 \:\text{cm}^2) \times 8.23\:\dfrac{\text{g}}{{\text{cm}}^3} \times \dfrac{1}{29\:\text{g}}\times 6.022\times 10^{23} \amp = 1.44\times 10^{22}.

solution.title: (c)
solution.p:
(c) There are 29 times as many electrons in copper as there are conducting electrons.
\text{Total} = 29\times 1.44\times 10^{22} = 4.17\times10^{23}.

solution.title: (d)
solution.p:
(d) The drift speed of conducting electrons is related to the conduction electron density and current density.
J = e n v.
The density of conduction electrons can be found from the number of electrons in the volume within one-inch length we calculated above.
n = \dfrac{1.44\times 10^{22}}{2.54\:\text{cm}\times 0.0331 \:\text{cm}^2} = 1.71 \times 10^{23}\:\text{cm}^{-3}.
Hence,
v \amp = \dfrac{J}{e n} \amp = \dfrac{6.05\times 10^{5}\:\text{A}/\text{m}^2}{1.6\times 10^{-19}\:\text{C}\times 1.71 \times 10^{27}\:\text{m}^{-3}} = 22\:\text{m/s}.

exercise.title: Surface Current Density in an Aluminum Plate

statement.p: How much current flows if the current density on the surface of an aluminum plate of width 3 \text{ cm} is 20 \text{ A/m}?

hint.p: Use definition of surface current density.

solution.p:
This is an exercise in using the definition of surface current density K.
I = K\:L_\perp = 20\:\dfrac{\text{A}}{\text{m}}\times 0.03\:\text{m} = 0.6\:\text{A}.

exercise.title: Current Through Different Parts of a Cross-Section of a Steel Wire

statement.p: A steel cylindrical rod of radius 5 \text{ cm} carries 30 \text{ amps} of current uniformly spread through out its cross section. (a) How much current flows within 1 \text{ cm} of its center? (b) How much current flows between 2 \text{ cm} and 3 \text{ cm} of its center? (c) How much of the current flows between 4 \text{ cm} and 5 \text{ cm} of its center?

solution.p:
Since the current is uniformly distributed throughout the cross-section, the current density is not dependent on the distance from the axis and found to be
J = \dfrac{I}{A} = \dfrac{30\:\text{A}}{\pi\times 0.05^2\:\text{m}^2} = 3.82\times 10^3\:\text{A/m}^2
Now we use the current density to solve different parts of the problem.

(a) Only the current passing through the area of cross-section matters.
I = J\:A = 3.82\times 10^3\:\text{A/m}^2 \times (\pi\times 0.01^2\:\text{m}^2) = 1.2\:\text{A}.

(b) Between 2 cm and 3 cm, the area of cross-section is different.
I = J\:A = 3.82\times 10^3\:\text{A/m}^2 \times [\pi (0.03^2 - 0.02^2 )\:\text{m}^2] = 6\:\text{A}.

(c) Between 4 cm and 5 cm the area of cross-section is even bigger.
I = J\:A = 3.82\times 10^3\:\text{A/m}^2 \times [\pi (0.05^2 - 0.04^2 )\:\text{m}^2] = 10.8\:\text{A}.
More exercise for you: Find the current through 1cm-2cm and 3cm-4cm and add up all the current to show that the total current is indeed 30 A.

exercise.title: (Calculus) Artificial Example of Current Density Varying Linearly Across Cross-Section of a Wire

statement.p: A 4-gauge wire of a special material of diameter 0.2038\text{ in} carries 10\text{ amp} current with a non-uniform current density across the cross-section of the wire. The current density increases linearly with distance from the center, J = a s, with constant a=5\text{ A/m}^3 and s is the distance from the axis of the wire in m. Find current flowing within 0.1\text{ mm} of the outer surface, and compare it with the current that flows within 0.1\text{ mm} of the center.

hint.p: Use I = \int J dA for the appropriate area.

solution.p:
Let us first convert radius R of the wire in metric unit.
R = \dfrac{0.2038\:\text{in}}{2} = 2.59\times 10^{-3}\:\text{m}.
The relation between the current density and total current can be used to find the constant a.
\int\: J\:dA \ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ \int\: J\: 2\pi s ds\ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ 2\pi a\int_0^R\: s^2\: ds = I.
Hence,
a = \dfrac{3 I}{2\pi R^3} = \dfrac{3\times 10\:\text{A}}{2\pi (2.59\times 10^{-3}\:\text{m})^3} = 2.75\times 10^{8}\:\text{A/m}^3.
The current flowing within 0.1 mm of the outer surface is found by integrating J there.
I = 2\pi a \int_{R-d}^R\: s^2\: ds = \dfrac{2\pi a}{3}\:\left[ R^3 - (R-d)^3 \right]= 9.42\:\text{A}.
The current flowing within 0.1 mm of the axis has different limits on the integral.
I = 2\pi a \int_0^d\: s^2\: ds = \dfrac{2\pi a}{3}\:d^3 = 1.73\:\text{A}.

exercise.title: (Calculus) Artificial Example of Current Density That Drops With Distance From Axis

statement.p: A 10-gauge wire of a special material diameter 0.102 \text{in} carries 10 \text{amp} current with a non-uniform current density. The current density increases with distance from the center as given by J=\frac{a}{b^2+s^2}, with constant a= 10 \text{ A}, b=0.1 \text{ m} , and s is the distance from the axis of the wire in \text{m}. Find current flowing within 0.1 \text{ mm} of the outer surface, and compare it with the current that flows within 0.1 \text{ mm} of the center.

hint.p: Use I = \int J dA for the appropriate area.

solution.p:
Let us first convert the radius R of the wire in metric unit.
R = \dfrac{0.102\:\text{in}}{2} = 1.3\times 10^{-3}\:\text{m}.
The relation between the current density and total current can be used to find the constant a.
\int\: J\:dA \ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ \int\: J\: 2\pi s ds\ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ 2\pi a\int_0^R\: \dfrac{s\: ds}{s^2+1} = I.
Hence,
a = \dfrac{I}{\pi\:\ln(R+1)} = \dfrac{10\:\text{A}}{\pi\times \ln(1.0013)} = 2450\:\text{A}.
The current flowing within 0.1 mm of the outer surface is found by integrating J there.
I = 2\pi a \int_{R-d}^R\: \dfrac{s\: ds}{s^2+1} = \pi a \ln\left( \dfrac{R+1}{R-d-1} \right) = 0.7687\:\text{A}.
The current flowing within 0.1 mm of the axis has different limits on the integral.
I = 2\pi a \int_0^d\: \dfrac{s\: ds}{s^2+1}= \pi a \ln\left( d+1\right) = 0.7697\:\text{A}.
